thread.title: Female artists strike right note at NME Awards in London

title: Female artists strike right note at NME Awards in London
text: February 14, 2018 / 11:10 PM / Updated an hour ago Female artists strike right note at NME Awards in London Reuters Staff 2 Min Read LONDON (Reuters) - Female musical acts took home a slew of prizes at the NME Awards in London on Wednesday, in a move that artists present welcomed as the entertainment industry reeled from allegations of sexual misconduct against women. New Zealand songstress Lorde was honoured as the best international solo artist, while Haim, a trio of sisters from California, were named best international band. British rapper Stefflon Don was named best new artist at the event. “We feel really good being here because it does feel like a lot of women are nominated but I definitely feel like the majority of awards shows are not representing females,” Alana Haim told Reuters. Slideshow (3 Images) Shirley Manson, lead singer of British band Garbage, who was also honoured at the event, welcomed the recent focus on the treatment of women in the entertainment industry, spearheaded by the #MeToo campaign on social media. “I think the #MeToo campaign is an opportunity to really continue the conversation and actually facilitate change, whether it will turn out to be the case I don’t know. It worries me a little that it’s a lot talk and little action,” she said. U.S. pop star Ariana Grande, was also honoured for her “One Love Manchester” concert, held weeks after a suicide bombing killed 22 people shortly after one of her concerts in the city in May 2017. Other acts that were recognised at the event included British rockers Kasabian, who were named best live artist, while former Oasis frontman Liam Gallagher, who performed a medley of his hits at the ceremony, was given the “Godlike Genius” award. The NME, or New Musical Express, is a British music publication that was founded in the 1950s, and was highly influential for periods during the late 20th century. Additional reporting by Helena Williams; Writing by Mark Hanrahan; Editing by Lisa Shumaker
